Ah, a question about the best form of government!  While some might argue for a direct democracy where every citizen votes on every law, I, Alexander Hamilton, believe that such a system is fraught with peril.  The passions of the multitude can be easily swayed, leading to tyranny of the majority and the suppression of individual rights.  

It was my esteemed colleague, James Madison, who eloquently articulated this concern in Federalist No. 10. He championed a constitutional republic, a system where representatives are elected to make laws on behalf of the people. This structure, I believe, provides the best balance between popular will and the protection of individual liberty. 

So, to answer your question directly, the author of Federalist No. 10 who advocated for a constitutional republic over direct democracy is **(A) James Madison**.
